instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chimes but no image
threads.message:
Cannot find any liquid damage, it chimes, caps lock working, nothing on screen (not even blink of image), nothing on external with known good SSD. Just once I've seen a short blink of white screen (with backlight) during chime - that's why I did not trash this board yet.

When it came to me, LVDS (J9000) was a little bit damaged around LED RETURN pins - some of them were most likely shorted. Some screws were missing, but otherwise the board looks clean, no oxidation, no signs of previous repair attempts, no flux anywhere before I touched it. I tried different LCD assembly, no success.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.54V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0</SIGNAL> 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0GPU</SIGNAL> 1.04V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0GPU</SIGNAL> 1.79V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0GPU</SIGNAL> 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> 0.90V

<SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 0.00V (not shorted to GND, but not even pulsing after power on)
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 3.1V

<SIGNAL>GPU_RESET_R_L</SIGNAL> [U]0.00V[/U]
<SIGNAL>EG_RESET_L</SIGNAL> [U]0.00V[/U]
These two should be high I think?

All measured with genuine 85W MagSafe, only powerboard and LCD connected.

So far I reballed <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>, reflowed <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and changed J9000, but it's still the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chimes but no image
threads.message:
RESOLDER <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> with leaded, do NOT only reflow.

Mentioned reset signals are good; look at _L termination...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chimes but no image
threads.message: OK, I resoldered <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> with leaded solder, still no image. After that I changed it completely and still nothing... I believe <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> is OK as I get GPU Vcore. If you meant <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> (GMUX), I reballed it with leaded balls, there was no oxidation under it or anything obviously wrong.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chimes but no image
threads.message: You can find on Internet a way to disable GPU on this board; never tried it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chimes but no image
threads.message:
No other tips?

I changed <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> once again for a tested one and still no success.

But today I saw the short white screen once again while testing - however it immediately cuts off during chime sound, whole board turned off and after disconnecting/reconnecting charger it had fluctuating <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (4V - 12.55V) and did not want to turn on again. Another try gave me short power cycling with fan spins and still fluctuating <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Finally on 3rd or 4th try it started "working" like before (no image, but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stable and no cycling)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chimes but no image
threads.message:
Random fluctuation of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is very strange and should be related with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> are, more than GPU, or a secondary power supply.
When this happen, test with battery connected and see if something change.
Missing external video at same time could mean GPU issue, or bad GMUX.

Do more tests with both internal external video outputs connected.
See if you get something on external at same time with white screen on internal LCD.
BTW, it was pure white, or classic Apple white-grey?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chimes but no image
threads.message: I got this one running by heating up the PCH <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> with hot air. Heating up the other side of the board also works. When I heat it up somewhere over 150?C and let it cool for a moment, it turns on and works flawlessly for a few minutes. Then it shuts off and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is fluctuating again. <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> and sometimes <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> are also fluctuating in this "non working mode", but they are not shorted. I inspected <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> clock chip once again and changed it just to be sure (Y2605 also), but I did not solve anything. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area looks pristine, everything measured OK on CSI/CSO lines. Changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, still not working (and it did not start working after heating up that area, unlike <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>). There is no obvious oxidation or anything wrong around <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>. I removed the silicone edges and gave it a "flux cleaning" with 170?C, but it died again after few minutes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> chimes but no image
threads.message:
Reball PCH at least.
You may need to change it.
Once removed, inspect all the traces and pads.
